head.title: DNA Evidence Prompts a Murder Pardon

hedline.hl1: DNA Evidence Prompts a Murder Pardon

block.p: On the basis of a DNA test, Earl Washington Jr., a Virginia farmhand with an I.Q. of 69, was finally pardoned last week for a grisly rape-murder he never committed. Across his 17 years of imprisonment, most of them on death row, pro bono lawyers have complained that the police concocted his confession. But they ran afoul of the nation's toughest evidence bar -- a narrow 3-week window for submitting new exculpatory evidence after a conviction.

On the basis of a DNA test, Earl Washington Jr., a Virginia farmhand with an I.Q. of 69, was finally pardoned last week for a grisly rape-murder he never committed. Across his 17 years of imprisonment, most of them on death row, pro bono lawyers have complained that the police concocted his confession. But they ran afoul of the nation's toughest evidence bar -- a narrow 3-week window for submitting new exculpatory evidence after a conviction.
Under media pressure, Gov. James S. Gilmore III ordered a DNA test and granted an ''absolute pardon'' even as his office insisted the state's criminal justice system was far from flawed.
